Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EaSM2--Linking Human and Earth System Models to Assess Regional Impacts and Adaption in Urban Systems and Their Hinterlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Within the next three decades, climate variability, climate change and global development trends could have varied and profound effects on human well-being, especially in the developing world. Understanding how human and earth system trajectories will interact is essential to making better decisions that can reduce negative consequences for society and ecosystems. Research related to climate impacts has traditionally been separated into a number of poorly coordinated tasks, with independent models and research groups developing a) socio-economic development pathways, b) emissions and land use scenarios, c) land cover projections, d) climate simulations, and e) impact assessments. This disjointed approach has led to inconsistencies in assumptions across different components of the problem, lack of incorporation of feedbacks, unmanaged uncertainty propagation, and introduction of errors when upscaling or downscaling information across components.

To address these issues, better approaches to impact assessment are required that provide richer, higher resolution, and more internally consistent information about future societal and earth system conditions, and that link models of human and earth systems more effectively. The central objective of this proposal is to improve understanding of the joint consequences of socio-economic development and regional climate change by developing and applying tools to better integrate human and earth system models. This objective will be pursued by focusing on impacts in three key systems - urban areas, agriculture, and forests - in three regional case studies in rapidly developing countries - China, India, and Brazil. The project will develop an integrated suite of community tools for linking the most relevant type of global human system model, integrated assessment models (IAMs), with the Community Earth System Model (CESM), developed and validated through broad-based scientific collaboration and community support over the past 15 years. It will employ these tools to link the CESM with one IAM, the integrated Population-Economy-Technology-Science (iPETS) model, and carry out end-to-end impact assessments for our case study regions, from socio-economic scenario development through earth system analysis to impact and adaptation assessment. These assessments will serve as a proof-of-concept for this new modeling framework as well as produce valuable assessment information. Importantly, the research framework will be applicable in other human systems, in other regions, and with other IAMs than those employed here, to contribute to an even broader understanding of the human consequences of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ASU was a member of a multi-institutional, collaborative project to improve our understanding of the joint consequences of socio-economic development and regional climate change. This combined project, led by scientists at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) and several universities, including ASU, developed and applied tools to better integrate human and earth system models in urban and rural contexts. The ASU team contributed most directly to integrative modeling of social and environmental processes in urban areas, specifically by:

1. Providing a new and more accurate global, gridded data set to represent the structural morphology of urban areas (e.g., location and dimensions of buildings, roads, green space, etc). 

2. Creating software in Python (based on earlier code in NCAR NCL) to assign building materials with different thermal properties to urban areas (e.g., by assigning them to buildings of different dimensions) to model their impacts on climate and people.

3. Developing a web-based graphical user interface to the Python software to make it easier for researchers to design experiments on the climate and social impacts of current and potential future cities under current and potential climate conditions. 

DATASETS

The ASU team reclassified, rescaled, and reformatted the global GHSL (Global Human Settlement Layers - https://ghsl.jrc.ec.europa.eu) land use data to be compatible with the current modeling protocols of the Community Land Model (CLM), and potentially compatible with the international Local Climate Zone (LCZ) classification system of the World Urban Database (http://wudapt.org). ASU provided these new datasets to NCAR, along with comparative assessments of the new dataset with the dataset from Jackson and colleagues used previously. The new GBHL-derived data seem to better match the distribution and extent of global cities than does Jackson and colleagues. Using our new dataset, NCAR carried out preliminary modeling experiments to evaluate the differences between the new data and the Jackson data. They are dramatic, indicating potentially much greater impact of urban areas on energy use, heat island, and regional/global climate than previously estimated. Further evaluation and sensitivity testing is needed to verify these initial results, and is ongoing.

SOFTWARE

The ASU team created computer code in the Python language for designing and carrying our modeling experiments on the thermal properties of urban areas. This reads several text databases in csv format--construction materials, thermal properties of this material, how this material is applied to buildings of different dimensions, and what parts of the world these construction materials will be used--and then combines this information with a global urban morphology gridded data set (see #1) to produce a resulting gridded data set (NetCDF format) that can be used by the CLM. This makes it possible to model in detail the local, regional, and global impacts of urban morphology on climate and city inhabitants. 

These procedures were previously written as scripts in the NCAR Command Language (NCL). ASU rewrote this in Python, the most widely used language for science and data analytics today. The resulting code is much more streamlined and easier to use by a much wider potential audience. The code has been provided to NCAR, where it is being tested it to verify that it gives results equivalent to the old NCL code.

INTERFACES

The ASU team completed a web based interface to the Python code for applying thermal properties to modeled buildings, described above, that provides an interactive GUI environment for designing experiments and setting parameterizations for modeling the thermal and energy impacts of current urban morphology and future scenarios. The code is developed in the ChainBuilder workflow environment and packaged as a widely useable Docker container that can be downloaded and used by the scientific and modeling communities. It is also provided to NCAR for distribution.
